title: How to Write Christening Invitations

steps.headline: Decide who is hosting the event and sending the invitations.
steps.description: This will usually be the parents or the godparents.

steps.headline: Choose the style of invitation you want.
steps.description: Some people like formal, printed invitations and others prefer digital invites that can be emailed.

steps.headline: Select the invitations you will send.
steps.description: Whether you print them out yourself or use a stationer or print shop, there will be a variety of styles to choose from.

steps.headline: Examine how and where your text will fit.
steps.description: Unless there is a photo or graphic included, you will want to have the wording centered on the invite. Work the text around any graphics you include. Some invitations have pictures or photos. You can include a picture of the baby who will be christened, or a religious graphic such as a cross. Not all invitations have a graphic, but some people choose to include a picture.

steps.headline: Extend an invitation with one line or phrase.
steps.description: For example, "Please join us for the Christening of" or "help us celebrate the Christening of" are good ways to start.

steps.headline: Mention the child's name.
steps.description: Your guests will need to know who is being christened. Eg: Arianna.

steps.headline: List all other pertinent information.
steps.description: Include the date of the christening and the time it will be held. Share the name and address of the church where the christening will be held. Include the location of your reception or gathering if there is room on the invitation, otherwise this information can be shared separately by word of mouth or announced at the service.

steps.headline: Experiment with various ways to word the information.
steps.description: Use a quote from scripture if you want, or keep the invitation simple and informative.

steps.headline: Look for samples that you can follow.
steps.description: Most stationery providers will have sample text that you can use when you write out your invitation.

steps.headline: Ask for RSVPs.
steps.description: Provide invited guests with an RSVP card, a telephone number or an email address to confirm they will attend.

steps.headline: Choose a method for managing your digital invite.
steps.description: There are popular sites such as Evite, Ping and Punchbowl that can help you design and email a christening invitation.

steps.headline: Follow a template that is provided online.
steps.description: Provide the necessary information in the spaces provided. You will need to type in names, locations, dates and times. Add any additional text, such as passages from scripture or special messages to your guests. Most digital invites will instruct recipients how to RSVP, either by sending an automatic email or clicking on a button.
